description: A recommendation from my former university professor, Rick Neff, one of the most brilliant people I know. We are still in touch and discuss many of life's mysteries.

An electronic card-matching game I helped develop at Binary Cocoa. I took the rough code, refined the mechanics, added a tutorial, all animations and polish. I published the game to Apple and Google Play stores (not currently available on Apple). Download it at the Google Play store.

Final project for Front End Web Development II. Get earthquake data from anywhere in the world. This site uses a couple of APIs and the Leafelt map library. Earthquake results are populated on a map with custom markers and popups.
Group project for Front End Web Development II. A mock shopping site for outdoor gear. We were given mostly functional code, which we modified over several weeks adding functionality and features.
An exercise in using a geolocation tracker and populating the user's location on a map.
An exercise in using canvas to draw shapes. Please don't make him angry.
An exercise in changing page properties based on page dimensions. The hamburger menu appears when screen is small and an alert is generated when the menu disappears.
A simple exercise in html form verification
An exercise in creating a simple entry form in HTML

A game-like security key generator for cryptocurrency. This was a commissioned project. The concept being that you do not need to write down your security key. Instead, go through the exact same activities on this game and it will produce your security key. You only need to remember what activities you did in the proper order. To my knowledge this has not been put into production and cannot be accessed online.
This is my first published book narration. You can listen to the sample on Audible.
A simple exercise in changing parameters in an API
A simple exercise in creating JSON to capture results from an API
